chapter.subject: Physics
chapter.chapter_name: Pressure in fluids and atmospheric pressure

questions.question_text: What is thrust?

options.label: B
options.text: Force acting normally on a surface.

questions.key_concept: Thrust is defined as force acting normally (perpendicularly) on a surface.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a vector quantity?
questions.key_concept: Thrust is a vector quantity as it has both magnitude and direction. Pressure is scalar.

questions.question_text: A body of weight 20 N is placed on a horizontal surface in three different orientations. The thrust exerted by the body on the surface is:

options.label: A
options.text: Maximum when the body is placed on its largest face.

options.label: B
options.text: Minimum when the body is placed on its smallest face.

options.label: C
options.text: Different in the three orientations as the contact area changes.

questions.key_concept: Thrust exerted by a body on a surface is equal to its weight (for a horizontal surface), and is independent of the orientation or contact area. Pressure changes with area, not thrust.

questions.question_text: A block weighs 50 N. If it is placed on a table with its largest face (area 0.1 m²) down, what is the thrust on the table?
questions.key_concept: Thrust = Weight of the body = 50 N. Area is relevant for pressure, not thrust.

questions.question_text: How does thrust differ from pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: Thrust is a scalar, pressure is a vector.

options.label: B
options.text: Thrust is total normal force, pressure is thrust per unit area.

options.label: C
options.text: Thrust depends on area, pressure does not.

options.label: D
options.text: Thrust is measured in Pa, pressure in N.

questions.key_concept: Thrust is the total force (vector, unit N). Pressure is the thrust per unit area (scalar, unit Pa).

questions.question_text: Why is the thrust exerted by a person lying on sand the same as when standing, even though sinking depth differs?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the weight of the person changes with posture.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the area of contact is the same in both cases.

options.label: C
options.text: Because thrust (weight) is constant, but pressure differs due to change in area.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the density of sand changes with depth.

questions.key_concept: Thrust (weight) remains constant. Pressure = Thrust/Area. Lying increases area, decreasing pressure, hence less sinking.

questions.question_text: Pressure is defined as:
questions.key_concept: Pressure = Thrust / Area.

questions.question_text: The S.I. unit of pressure is:
questions.key_concept: 1 Pa = 1 N m⁻².

questions.question_text: A force of 10 N acts on an area of 2 m². Another force of 5 N acts on an area of 1 m². Which statement is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The first situation exerts greater thrust and greater pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: The second situation exerts less thrust but greater pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: Pressure cannot be compared without knowing the direction of force.

questions.key_concept: Thrust1=10N, P1=10/2=5 Pa. Thrust2=5N, P2=5/1=5 Pa? Wait, P2=5 Pa? Let's calculate: P1=5 Pa, P2=5 Pa. They are equal. The trap is in misreading. Re-check: P1 = 10N/2m² = 5 Pa. P2 = 5N/1m² = 5 Pa. So pressure is equal. The option saying greater pressure in second is false. The correct option should state they have the same pressure. Let's adjust: The question asks for correct statement. Option C says 'Both exert the same pressure.' That is true. But I must have a trap. The trap is that students might think larger force means larger pressure, ignoring area. I'll change values: Force1=10N on 4 m² => P=2.5 Pa. Force2=5N on 1 m² => P=5 Pa. Then B is correct: less thrust (5N vs 10N) but greater pressure (5 Pa vs 2.5 Pa).

questions.question_text: A brick of weight 20 N is placed on ground with its dimensions 20 cm x 10 cm x 5 cm. To exert minimum pressure on the ground, it should be placed with which face down?

options.label: D
options.text: Pressure is same in all orientations.

questions.key_concept: Minimum pressure requires maximum area. Largest area is 20 cm x 10 cm = 200 cm².

questions.question_text: Which of the following will increase pressure for a given thrust?

options.label: C
options.text: Keeping area constant but changing the material.

options.label: D
options.text: Applying thrust at an angle instead of normally.

questions.key_concept: Pressure P = F/A. For constant F (thrust), decreasing A increases P. Option B in original list is 'Decreasing the area of contact.' That's correct. But label must be unique. Let's reorder: A: Increasing area (false). B: Decreasing area (true). C: Keeping area constant (false). D: Applying at an angle (false, as thrust is defined as normal force).

questions.question_text: Why is the foundation of a building made wider than its walls?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the thrust on the ground.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the pressure on the ground by increasing the area.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the pressure on the ground for stability.

options.label: D
options.text: To allow water to seep through easily.

questions.key_concept: Wider foundation increases area (A), thus decreasing pressure (P = Weight/A) for the same thrust (weight of building), preventing excessive sinking.

questions.question_text: A fluid is a substance that:
questions.key_concept: Fluids include both liquids and gases because they can flow.

questions.question_text: How does fluid pressure act at a point?

options.label: B
options.text: Only in the direction of gravity.

questions.key_concept: Fluid pressure at a point is transmitted equally in all directions.

questions.question_text: A hole is made in the wall of a vessel containing water. The water spurts out. What does this demonstrate?

options.label: B
options.text: Water exerts pressure on the wall at that point.

questions.key_concept: The spurting shows that liquid exerts pressure sideways on the container walls, not just downward.

questions.question_text: In an experiment with a vessel having holes at different depths, the liquid spurts out farthest from the hole that is:

options.label: B
options.text: At the greatest depth below the free surface.

options.label: C
options.text: At the middle of the vessel.

questions.key_concept: Pressure increases with depth (P = hρg), so greater depth results in greater pressure and hence a faster, farther jet.

questions.question_text: How does pressure exerted by a solid differ from that exerted by a fluid?

options.label: A
options.text: Solid pressure acts only downwards; fluid pressure acts in all directions.

options.label: B
options.text: Solid pressure depends on depth; fluid pressure does not.

options.label: C
options.text: Fluid pressure is always less than solid pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: Solid pressure is transmitted equally in all directions; fluid pressure is not.

questions.key_concept: A solid exerts pressure only on the surface it is in contact with (usually downwards). A fluid exerts pressure in all directions due to its ability to flow.

questions.question_text: Why does a diver experience more pressure at greater depths in the sea?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the density of water decreases with depth.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the weight of the water column above increases with depth.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the atmospheric pressure increases with depth.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the temperature decreases with depth.

questions.key_concept: Pressure at a depth h is P = hρg, directly proportional to depth (height of fluid column above).

concepts.concept_name: Pressure due to a Liquid Column (P = hρg)

questions.question_text: The pressure at a depth h in a liquid of density ρ is given by:
questions.key_concept: The fundamental formula for pressure due to a liquid column: P = hρg.

questions.question_text: Which of the following does NOT affect the pressure at a point inside a stationary liquid?
questions.key_concept: Pressure P = hρg depends only on h, ρ, and g. It is independent of the shape or size of the container (law of liquid pressure).

questions.question_text: The total pressure at a depth h in a liquid open to the atmosphere is:
questions.key_concept: Total pressure = Atmospheric pressure (acting on the free surface) + Pressure due to liquid column (hρg). A common mistake is to forget atmospheric pressure.

questions.question_text: If the density of sea water is greater than river water, the pressure at the same depth will be:
questions.key_concept: P = hρg, for same h and g, pressure ∝ density. Higher density gives higher pressure.

questions.question_text: At the same depth in two liquids of different densities, the ratio of pressures is equal to the ratio of their:
questions.key_concept: P1/P2 = (hρ1g)/(hρ2g) = ρ1/ρ2, since h and g are same.

questions.question_text: Why is the wall of a dam made thicker at the bottom?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce the cost of construction at the top.

options.label: B
options.text: To withstand the increasing pressure with depth, as P = hρg.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the dam look aesthetically pleasing.

questions.key_concept: Liquid pressure increases with depth (h). The bottom experiences the greatest pressure and needs a thicker wall to withstand it.

questions.question_text: Which law of liquid pressure states that 'pressure increases with depth'?
questions.key_concept: First law: Inside a liquid, pressure increases with the increase in depth from its free surface.

questions.question_text: In a stationary liquid, pressure at all points on the same horizontal plane is:
questions.key_concept: Second law: In a stationary liquid, pressure is same at all points on a horizontal plane.

questions.question_text: A liquid seeks its own level. This is a consequence of:

options.label: A
options.text: Pressure being same at all points at the same depth.

questions.key_concept: Liquid seeks its own level (Fifth law) because pressure at points in connected vessels at the same horizontal level must be equal.

questions.question_text: Two holes are made at the same height on the wall of a water tank. The jets of water coming out will:

options.label: A
options.text: Have different ranges depending on hole size.

options.label: C
options.text: The lower hole jet will go farther.

options.label: D
options.text: The upper hole jet will go farther.

questions.key_concept: Since pressure depends on depth, and holes are at same height (same depth), pressure is equal, leading to equal initial speed and hence equal range (ignoring other factors).

questions.question_text: How does pressure at the same depth in two different liquids compare?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the same regardless of density.

options.label: B
options.text: It is higher in the liquid with higher density.

options.label: C
options.text: It is higher in the liquid with lower density.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the shape of the container.

questions.key_concept: Fourth law: Pressure at same depth is different in different liquids. It increases with increase in density (P = hρg).

questions.question_text: Why does a gas bubble grow in size as it rises from the bottom of a lake?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the temperature increases as it rises.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the pressure on it decreases (P = hρg decreases with depth), allowing expansion.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it absorbs water as it rises.

options.label: D
options.text: Because its density increases with height.

questions.key_concept: Total pressure on bubble = Atmospheric pressure + hρg. As h decreases, pressure decreases. According to Boyle's law, volume increases at lower pressure.
